revision.text:
{{For|the film critic|Ty Burr}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Ty Burrell | image = Ty Burrell 3 2014.jpg | caption = Burrell in February 2014 | birth_name = Tyler Gerald Burrell | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1967|8|22}}{{cite news|last=Baker|first=Jeff|title=17 actors you (maybe) didn't know were from Oregon|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/movies/index.ssf/2014/04/17_actors_you_maybe_didn.html |accessdate=2016-02-16|newspaper=[[The Oregonian]]|location=Portland, Oregon|date=April 30, 2014}} | birth_place = [[Grants Pass, Oregon]], U.S. | education = [[Hidden Valley High School (Grants Pass, Oregon)|Hidden Valley High School]] | alma_mater = [[Southern Oregon University]]
[[University of Oregon]]
[[Penn State University]] ([[Master of Fine Arts|MFA]]) | occupation = Actor, comedian | salary = $13.5 million (2017) | years_active = 2000–present | spouse = {{marriage|Holly Burrell|2000}} | children = 2 }} '''Tyler Gerald Burrell''' (born August 22, 1967) is an American actor and comedian. He originally rose to prominence in several roles on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] including ''[[Macbeth]]'', and the [[off-Broadway]] plays ''Corners'', ''[[The Blue Demon]]'', ''[[Burn This]]'', and ''Show People''. His first feature film role was in 2001's ''[[Evolution (2001 film)|Evolution]]''. He also appeared in ''[[Black Hawk Down (film)|Black Hawk Down]]'', ''[[Dawn of the Dead (2004 film)|Dawn of the Dead]]'', ''[[Muppets Most Wanted]]'' and [[Marvel Studios|Marvel's]] ''[[The Incredible Hulk (film)|The Incredible Hulk]]'' as [[Doc Samson]]. He has since voiced characters in a number of animated films ''[[Mr. Peabody & Sherman]]'', ''[[Finding Dory]]'' as "Bailey" the [[Beluga Whale]] and ''[[Storks (film)|Storks]]''. Burrell had recurring roles on the television series ''[[Out of Practice]]'' and ''[[Back to You (TV series)|Back to You]]''. Burrell is best known for his role as [[Phil Dunphy (Modern Family)|Phil Dunphy]] in the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] [[sitcom]] ''[[Modern Family]]'', for which he has won the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series]] in 2011 and 2014 and five [[Screen Actors Guild Awards]]: one for [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Comedy Series|Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Comedy Series]] in 2013 and four consecutive awards for [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Comedy Series|Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Comedy Series]] shared with the cast from 2011 to 2014. == Early life == Burrell was born in [[Grants Pass]], [[Oregon]],{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0123092/bio|title=Ty Burrell|website=IMDb}} the son of Sheri Rose (née Hauck), a teacher, and Gary Gerald Burrell (1940–1989), a family therapist.[http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20367251,00.html What I Learned from My Mom: The Men of Modern Family]. ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine. Retrieved on September 9, 2015.{{cite news|author=Staff|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/10698819/Ty-Burrell-interview-Modern-Family-has-normalised-gay-marriage.html|title=Ty Burrell interview: 'Modern Family has normalised gay marriage'|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=May 28, 2014}}{{cite news|last=Varble|first=Bill|url=http://www.mailtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071021/LIFE/710210313|title=This Just In|newspaper=[[Mail Tribune]]|location=Medford, Oregon|date=October 21, 2007|accessdate=May 28, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022131611/http://www.mailtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20071021%2FLIFE%2F710210313|archivedate=October 22, 2014|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|url=http://www.mailtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20020918/NEWS/309189983&cid=sitesearch|title=Former Medford principal, coach 'Gabby' Williams dies|newspaper=[[Mail Tribune]]|location=Medford, Oregon|accessdate=May 28, 2014}} He is of mostly English and German descent. According to the television series ''[[Finding Your Roots]]'', Burrell's great-great-great-great-grandmother Susanna Weeks was a former slave from Tennessee who became a [[homesteader]] in Oregon, and her son George Washington Weeks, would eventually [[pass for white]].https://bangordailynews.com/2016/01/08/living/family-ties/modern-family-star-grateful-to-black-pioneer-ancestor/Stated on ''[[Finding Your Roots]]'', January 5, 2016, PBS Burrell grew up in the small southern Oregon town of [[Applegate, Oregon|Applegate]], near the [[California]] border.{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/movies/index.ssf/2009/11/actor_ty_burrell_from_grants_p.html|title=Actor Ty Burrell: From Grants Pass to ABC's hit comedy 'Modern Family'|last=Turnquist|first=Kristi|date=November 28, 2009|work=[[The Oregonian]]|accessdate=November 29, 2009}}Stated on ''[[Inside the Actors Studio]]'', 2011 He attended [[Hidden Valley High School (Grants Pass, Oregon)|Hidden Valley High School]] in Grants Pass, where he played [[American football|football]] and was a lineman for the Hidden Valley Mustangs. After graduating, he enrolled at [[Southern Oregon University]] in [[Ashland, Oregon|Ashland]], and graduated with a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[theatre arts]] in 1993; he was the school's [[Commencement speech|commencement speaker]] in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.sou.edu/president/speeches/sept-16-08.html |title=Southern Oregon University: President's Page |last=Cullinan |first=Mary |date=September 16, 2008 |publisher=[[Southern Oregon University]] |accessdate=May 29, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528103909/http://www.sou.edu/president/speeches/sept-16-08.html |archivedate=May 28, 2010 }} While in college, he worked as a bartender at the [[Oregon Shakespeare Festival]]. During this time, Burrell attended the [[University of Oregon]] and became a member of the Sigma Chi Fraternity.[http://web.sigmachi.org/news/sigs-making-headlines Sigma Chi making headlines]. Web.sigmachi.org (August 4, 2012). Retrieved on 2015-09-09. He continued his education at [[Penn State University]], where he earned an [[Master of Fine Arts|MFA]] and was a member of the Theatre 100 Company along with [[Keegan-Michael Key]].[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/14/arts/television/key-peele-on-comedy-central-starts-second-season.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 Comedy Central starts second season], ''[[The New York Times]]'', October 14, 2014; accessed September 9, 2014.{{cite news|last1=Federowicz|first1=Jeffrey Allen|title=PSU grad fits right in with 'Out of Practice'|url=http://www.thestate.com/mld/centredaily/living/13779535.htm?source=rss&channel=centredaily_living|accessdate=November 22, 2014|work=[[Centre Daily Times]]|date=February 4, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060224210728/http://www.thestate.com/mld/centredaily/living/13779535.htm?source=rss&channel=centredaily_living|archivedate=February 24, 2006}} In 1999, Burrell worked as a festival actor at the Utah Shakespeare Festival. Burrell has also stated that for a period of time in graduate school, he lived out of his van to save money.{{cite news|url=http://www.elle.com/Pop-Culture/Celebrity-Spotlight/Ty-Burrell-Modern-Family/Modern-Man |title=Modern Man |magazine=[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]] |date=March 31, 2011 |accessdate=May 28, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120114113437/http://www.elle.com/Pop-Culture/Celebrity-Spotlight/Ty-Burrell-Modern-Family/Modern-Man |archivedate=January 14, 2012 }} == Career == Burrell's first credited film roles were 2001's ''[[Evolution (2001 film)|Evolution]]'' and ''[[Black Hawk Down (film)|Black Hawk Down]]''. He subsequently appeared in the 2004 remake of ''[[Dawn of the Dead (2004 film)|Dawn of the Dead]]'', and in several stage roles (like 2000's [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] production of ''[[Macbeth]]'', and the [[off-Broadway]] plays ''Corners'', ''[[The Blue Demon]]'', ''[[Burn This]]'', and ''Show People''). He was a co-writer and actor in the original production of the offbeat comedy ''The Red Herring O' Happiness'' directed by Russell Dyball. Burrell's stage work also includes writing and working in the off-Broadway play ''Babble'' with his brother, Duncan. He has also made an appearance as a New Jersey Prosecutor in ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]''. After that, he was cast as Oliver Barnes, a shallow but well-meaning [[plastic surgeon]], on the [[Columbia Broadcast System|CBS]] [[sitcom]] ''[[Out of Practice]]'' (2005–06), also created by [[Christopher Lloyd (screenwriter)|screenwriter Christopher Lloyd]]. The show was canceled in May 2006, with eight episodes remaining unaired in the United States. After the show's cancellation, he played [[Allan Arbus]] in the film ''[[Fur (film)|Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus]]''. In the Marvel film adaptation of the comic ''[[The Incredible Hulk (film)|The Incredible Hulk]],'' he played Leonard Samson (without superpowers), who had a short relationship with Betty Ross. In 2007, he had a small role in the film ''[[National Treasure: Book of Secrets]]'' as the [[White House Office of the Curator|curator]] of the [[White House]] followed by a starring role in the sitcom ''[[Back to You (TV series)|Back to You]]'' on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] later that same year. On the show, created by [[Steven Levitan]] and [[Christopher Lloyd (screenwriter)|Christopher Lloyd]], Burrell played a [[field reporter]] (alongside [[Kelsey Grammer]] and [[Patricia Heaton]]). The show was canceled in 2008. His current role is as a realtor Phil Dunphy in the acclaimed [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] situation comedy ''[[Modern Family]]'' which is also created by Christopher Lloyd and Steve Levitan. For his performance, he has received eight consecutive [[Primetime Emmy Award]] nominations for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series (2010–2017), winning the award twice in 2011 and 2014.[http://www.emmys.com/celebrities/ty-burrell Ty Burrell Emmy Award Winner]. Emmys.com. Retrieved on September 9, 2015. He also received nominations for the [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Comedy Series]] for his role, sharing the [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Comedy Series]] with his co stars. He was the recipient of the individual SAG award in 2014, defeating [[Alec Baldwin]], who had previously won the award seven years in a row.[http://www.webpronews.com/ty-burrell-dethrones-alec-baldwin-at-the-sag-awards-2014-01 Ty Burrell Dethrones Alec Baldwin at the SAG Awards]. WebProNews (January 19, 2014). Retrieved on 2015-09-09. Burrell also appears as Phil in commercials for [[National Association of Realtors]].{{cite news|url=http://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/national-association-realtors-finds-its-perfect-pitchman-modern-family-dad-171283/|title=The National Association of Realtors Finds Its Perfect Pitchman in Modern Family Dad|first=David|last=Gianatasio|work=[[Adweek]]|date=May 5, 2016}} In November 2014, Burrell inked an overall deal with [[20th Century Fox Television]] to develop his own comedy projects.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/tv/news/1201349693-1201349693/ |title=Ty Burrell Signs Overall Deal with Twentieth Century Fox TV |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |first=Debra |last=Birnbaum |date=November 6, 2014 |accessdate=July 20, 2017}} His web series ''[[Boondoggle (web series)|Boondoggle]]'', loosely based on Burrell's own life, debuted in June 2016 on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC.com]] and [[ABCd]].{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2016/07/13/abc-digital-series-online-only/ |title=ABC Is Introducing Dozens of New Shows You Can Only Watch Online |work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |first=Tom |last=Huddleston Jr. |date=July 13, 2016 |accessdate=July 20, 2017}} He was nominated for the [[Primetime Emmy Award]] for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Actor in a Short Form Comedy or Drama Series|Outstanding Actor in a Short Form Comedy or Drama Series]] in July 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/awards/nominees-winners/2017/outstanding-actor-in-a-short-form-comedy-or-drama-series |title=Nominees/Winners | Television Academy |publisher=[[Academy of Television Arts & Sciences]] |date= |accessdate=July 20, 2017}} == Personal life == Burrell and his wife Holly married on August 18, 2000. They resided in [[New York City]] until moving to [[Salt Lake City]]{{cite news|url=http://www.sltrib.com/tv/ci_13910925|title='Modern Family' Star Calls Utah Home |newspaper=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|location=Salt Lake City|date=December 3, 2009|accessdate=November 4, 2014}} in 2008. They still own a two-bedroom apartment in the [[Astoria, Queens]] neighborhood that they rent out.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703303904575292750887594886|title=Television's Prime Time Wiener|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=June 8, 2010|accessdate=March 19, 2012}} The couple have since relocated to Southern California for Burrell's work on ''Modern Family''. On March 18, 2010, it was announced that Burrell and his wife had adopted a baby, a daughter. Two years later, they adopted another daughter, Greta.{{cite web|url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2010/03/18/modern-familys-ty-burrell-adopts-a-daughter|title=Modern Family's Ty Burrell Adopts a Daughter|publisher=Celebritybabies.people.com|date=March 18, 2010|accessdate=February 18, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2012/03/19/modern-family-ty-burrell-adopts-daughter|title=Ty Burrell Welcomes a Daughter|magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=March 19, 2012|accessdate=March 19, 2012}} Burrell is a self-described lifelong fan of the [[Oregon Ducks]], [[Portland Trail Blazers]], [[New York Mets]] and [[St. Louis Rams]] (which has since been relocated to California and renamed as the [[Los Angeles Rams]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.therams.com/videos/videos/Why-Im-a-Rams-Fan-Ty-Burrell/fec323dd-93c0-494d-a154-c73a82fa09da|title=Why I'm a Rams Fan: Ty Burrell|publisher=}} == Filmography == === Film === {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Notes |- | 2001 | ''[[Evolution (2001 film)|Evolution]]'' | Colonel Flemming | |- | 2001 | ''[[Black Hawk Down (film)|Black Hawk Down]]'' | Timothy A.
